arm_group.description: Total laparoscopic hysterectomy, laparoscopic assisted vaginal hysterectomy

brief_summary.textblock:
The purpose of the proposed pilot study is to investigate the effectiveness, cost, safety,
      and long-term impact on quality of life of laparoscopic hysterectomy (LH) in relation to
      abdominal hysterectomy (AH) for the treatment of benign gynecologic disease in women through
      a randomized surgical trial.

      The overall hypothesis is that neither mode of hysterectomy will be consistently superior to
      the other with respect to each of the three domains of complications, cost, and
      patient-centered outcomes. The overall goal of the study is to determine which clinically
      relevant factors may impact the choice of LH compared to AH.  The results of the study may
      be useful for clinicians, patients, hospital administrators and health policy makers.

clinical_study.brief_title: Surgical Success After Laparoscopic vs Abdominal Hysterectomy

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:

          -  Women undergoing hysterectomy for benign indications within 8 weeks of enrollment

          -  Women >18 years of age

          -  Non-emergent surgery

          -  Non-pregnant

        Exclusion Criteria:

          -  Candidate for vaginal hysterectomy

          -  Uterine size >14 weeks by clinical exam OR >300 mL by ultrasound measurement

          -  History of cancer of reproductive tract

          -  Requires concomitant pelvic organ prolapse (POP) surgery

          -  Requires surgery for urinary incontinence

          -  Has acute angle glaucoma

          -  Has severe cardiac/respiratory disease

          -  Desires supracervical hysterectomy

clinical_study.official_title: Randomized Trial of Laparoscopic Versus Abdominal Hysterectomy for Benign Indications and Impact on Surgical Success

overall_official.affiliation: University of Texas Southwestern Medical Center

primary_outcome.description:
1) Patient-centered outcomes composite
Quality of life -  measured using the Short Form 12 (SF-12v2),
Sexual functioning - measured using the Sexual Activity Questionnaire (SAQ)
Body image - measured using the Body Image Scale (BIS)
Return to normal activity -measured using the Activities Assessment Scale (AAS)
Pain - measured using a 10 point likert scale
Productivity - measured using a questionnaire about missed work

required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on June 04, 2014
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

responsible_party.investigator_affiliation: University of Texas Southwestern Medical Center
responsible_party.investigator_title: Assistant Professor, Department of Obstetrics and Gynecology

secondary_outcome.description: Hospital charges and indirect costs of missed work/caregiving due to hysterectomy will be calculated
Intraoperative and postoperative complications including conversions, unintentional lacerations/injury to organs, hemorrhage, infection, wound complications, VTE, death, pain, neuropathy

clinical_study.source: University of Texas Southwestern Medical Center

lead_sponsor.agency: University of Texas Southwestern Medical Center

clinical_study.study_design: Allocation: Randomized, Endpoint Classification: Safety/Efficacy Study, Intervention Model: Parallel Assignment, Masking: Open Label, Primary Purpose: Health Services Research
